content.title: Diverticulitis
content.summary: Inflammation and/or infection of colonic diverticula, typically in the sigmoid colon, presenting with left lower quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis, ranging from uncomplicated to complicated disease with abscess, perforation, or fistula
key_points: Inflammation of colonic diverticula - sigmoid most common
LLQ pain + fever + leukocytosis = classic presentation
CT abdomen/pelvis is diagnostic test of choice
Hinchey classification stages severity of perforation
Colonoscopy 6-8 weeks after resolution to exclude cancer

statement.text: Diverticulitis is inflammation of colonic diverticula, most commonly in the sigmoid colon due to microperforation from fecalith obstruction. Patients present with LLQ pain, fever, and leukocytosis. CT confirms diagnosis and identifies complications. Uncomplicated diverticulitis may be managed with antibiotics or observation; complicated disease (abscess, perforation) requires drainage or surgery.
statement.formal: Diverticulitis = Diverticula + Inflammation/Microperforation | Uncomplicated = Antibiotics Â± NPO | Complicated = Drainage/Surgery

explanation.intuition: Diverticula are outpouchings in the colon wall that form at weak points where blood vessels penetrate. When stool gets trapped in a diverticulum, it can cause inflammation and microperforation - like an appendicitis but of the colon wall. Most cases are 'uncomplicated' and respond to antibiotics, but some progress to abscess or frank perforation.
explanation.key_insight: The sigmoid colon is most affected because it has the highest intraluminal pressure. Uncomplicated diverticulitis can often be managed outpatient; complicated disease (abscess, perforation, fistula) requires intervention. Always colonoscopy after recovery to rule out underlying malignancy.
explanation.technical_details: Hinchey Classification: I = pericolic abscess, II = pelvic abscess, III = purulent peritonitis, IV = fecal peritonitis. Small abscesses (<3cm) may resolve with antibiotics alone; larger need drainage. Colovesical fistula presents with pneumaturia and recurrent UTIs.

definitions_glossary.diverticulum: Outpouching of colonic wall at weak points
definitions_glossary.uncomplicated_diverticulitis: Inflammation without abscess, perforation, fistula, or obstruction
definitions_glossary.complicated_diverticulitis: With abscess, perforation, fistula, or obstruction
definitions_glossary.hinchey_classification: Staging system for perforated diverticulitis severity
definitions_glossary.colovesical_fistula: Abnormal connection between colon and bladder
definitions_glossary.sigmoid_colon: Most common location for diverticulitis in Western populations
definitions_glossary.microperforation: Small perforation contained by mesenteric fat
definitions_glossary.hartmann_procedure: Sigmoid resection with end colostomy for complicated disease

pathophysiology.mechanism: Diverticula form at points of penetration of vasa recta through circular muscle layer. Fecalith obstruction leads to mucosal erosion, microperforation, and inflammation. Contained perforation may wall off (abscess) or progress to free perforation (peritonitis).

imaging.ct: Gold standard - colonic wall thickening, pericolic fat stranding, abscess, free air
imaging.colonoscopy: Contraindicated acutely (perforation risk); perform 6-8 weeks later

uncomplicated.outpatient: Oral antibiotics (ciprofloxacin + metronidazole) or observation alone
uncomplicated.admission: If unable to tolerate PO, immunocompromised, or significant comorbidities

medicalCode.description: Diverticulitis of large intestine without perforation or abscess

learning_objectives: Diagnose diverticulitis clinically and with CT findings
Select appropriate management based on severity
clinical_pearls: LLQ pain + fever + leukocytosis = diverticulitis until proven otherwise
CT is gold standard - don't scope acutely
Abscess >3cm = drain; <3cm = antibiotics alone may work
Colonoscopy 6-8 weeks after to rule out cancer
common_misconceptions: All diverticulitis needs antibiotics (false - some uncomplicated can be observed)
Colonoscopy should be done during acute episode (false - wait 6-8 weeks)
